texts.definition: A special weakness that can be exploited to cause defeats easier than can be done by using the other means available.
markups: <style="Definition">A special weakness that can be exploited to cause defeats easier than can be done by using the other means available.</style>

Many of the more difficult enemies in games can more easily, or in some cases only, be defeated by a special form of attack. These kinds of enemies have <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style>, special vulnerabilities that players can use to their advantage if they can locate it or gain knowledge about it. More rarely, the avatars or characters under players control have <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> and then these need to be protected or kept secret.

The final boss monster in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Half-Life">Half-Life</link></style> can only be killed by first destroyed a number of crystals in the environment and then hitting a small gem inside its head. In <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/The%20Legend%20of%20Zelda%20series">The Legend of Zelda series</link></style> and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Super%20Mario%20series">Super Mario series</link></style>, boss monsters (and some enemies) can usually only be defeated by special actions, such as grabbing hold of the enemies' tail and spinning around rapidly or hitting the enemies' so that it shows a vulnerable spot and then hitting that spot.

The idea of placing your soul or heart in a jar to become unkillable as long as the jar is not destroyed is a common feature in folklore. Both <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Dungeons%20&%20Dragons">Dungeons & Dragons</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/GURPS">GURPS</link></style> have spells that provide this effect to players or their enemies.

The <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mansions%20of%20Madness">Mansions of Madness</link></style> can be said to use <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> since the players' controlling investigators do not know the winning condition and all enemies can keep spawning until the condition is revealed.

The design of <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> requires the presence of a complete <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerability</link></style> but then makes this incomplete by inserting a <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerability</link></style> - for this reason <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> both modulates and is in conflict with <style="Link"><link="invulnerabilities">Invulnerabilities</link></style>. The two main design choices regarding <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> is who has them and what is required to exploit them.

While <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style> under players' control can be given <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> it is more common to give it to <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style> specifically, since letting players have nearly invulnerable <style="Link"><link="focus-loci">Focus Loci</link></style> can make challenges too easy.

Making use of <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> may need specific <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tools">Tools</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style> and since this gives these an additional or specific purpose, <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> modulates these patterns. <style="Link"><link="aim-shoot">Aim & Shoot</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Timing">Timing</link></style> can also be needed to exploit <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style>, and these may all be combined to create more <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> when <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> have the <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style>.

<style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> can be used to let players more easily identify <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> during interaction with those that have them. In other circumstances, other types of <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> can be used - for example information divulged during <style="Link"><link="cutscenes">Cutscenes</link></style>.

<style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> are a form of <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerabilities</link></style> to otherwise invulnerable entities. By being the only way to defeat or <style="Link"><link="damage">Damage</link></style> these entities, <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> change how <style="Link"><link="combat">Combat</link></style> or other activities related to <style="Link"><link="eliminate">Eliminate</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="overcome">Overcome</link></style> goals can be achieved. The consequences of <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> depend one if they belong to an <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatar</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="characters">Character</link></style> under a player's control or to his or her <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style>. One of the effects that does however ''not'' depend on who has the them is that secret <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style>, or those that cannot be exploited due to missing <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Powers">Powers</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="weapons">Weapons</link></style>, are likely to lead to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Repeat%20Domination">Repeat Domination</link></style>. For this reason having information about <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> is <style="Link"><link="strategic-knowledge">Strategic Knowledge</link></style>, and likely to lead to both <style="Link"><link="strategic-planning">Strategic</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="tactical-planning">Tactical Planning</link></style> to either exploit or protect them.

In the case of <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemies</link></style> that have <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> (most common for <style="Link"><link="boss-monsters">Boss Monsters</link></style>), these provide <style="Link"><link="challenging-gameplay">Challenging Gameplay</link></style> in that they require players to identify a specific <style="Link"><link="vulnerabilities">Vulnerability</link></style> in otherwise invulnerable opponents. Trying to identify the exact nature of the <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style> are <style="Link"><link="gain-information">Gain Information</link></style> goals and trying to achieve them is likely done through <style="Link"><link="experimenting">Experimenting</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="puzzle-solving">Puzzle Solving</link></style>. The actual actions required to win over an <style="Link"><link="enemies">Enemy</link></style> with an <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heel</style> is likely to provide <style="Link"><link="varied-gameplay">Varied Gameplay</link></style>.

When players' <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="characters">Characters</link></style>, or <style="Link"><link="units">Units</link></style> have <style="CurrentLink">Achilles' Heels</style>, not letting others know about them leads to <style="Link"><link="conceal">Conceal</link></style> goals. If or when they are revealed, protecting them becomes a form of <style="Link"><link="evade">Evade</link></style> goal.
